results.title: The Repco-Brabham story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Production
results.brief_description: Briefly shows manufacture and testing of racing cars by the Brabham Racing Organisation in England, followed by views of the 1965 Tasman Series motor races in Australia and New Zealand, Jack Brabham and others competing in Brabham cars. Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

results.title: The People's land
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Donald Taylor and Strand Films
results.brief_description: In Britain the National Trust has acqired a number of estates and areas of land of historical interest: they include ancient castles, such as the 14th century Bodian castle, a Chiltern village, the famous valley of Dovedale, a number of prehistoric stone circles, 14,000 acres of Westmorland countryside and an extensive area of downland in Sussex. These estates and landmarks are held in public trust forever.

results.title: Solar dawn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Kay Roberts, Gareth Cole and Solarscope Films
results.brief_description: Utilises many animation sequences to clearly show how basic solar collectors work. It shows how buildings can be heated and cooled by solar devices, and how city buildings and ordinary houses should be designed to take advantage of direct solar energy.

results.title: Safety in your hands
results.creator_credit: Jill Robb, John Fitzgerald and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1974 film examines the responsibility of each worker for their own safety in the workplace. The film focuses particularly on protection of hands and eyes in industrial settings, showing a variety of machines operated by people. It demonstrates how untidiness, inattention, overconfidence and failure to use safety precautions such as safety glasses when operating these machines can lead to accidents. Footage of industrial workplaces is interspersed with footage of everyday accidents similarly caused by mess, distraction and overconfidence.

Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Skilled craftsmen: five Australians
results.creator_credit: Terry McMahon, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A lot of people consider craft a hobby. Something which is undertaken as a source of relaxation and self fulfilment. Many people, however, treat the crafts as a professional livelihood. This film shows the lifestyle of five of these people, each illustrating a different facet of the crafts: Joe McBain, a blacksmith; David Wright, a stained glass artist; Lilija Duks, a weaver; Greg Wain and Victoria Howlett, potters. Narrated by Rod Mullinar

results.title: The Story of Menstruation
results.brief_description: This film was made as an outgrowth of Disney’s contract work with the armed forces during World War II. “The Story of menstruation” was probably the first American educational film with a woman narrator. The first half of the film discusses the natural process of menstruation through colourful yet simple diagrams, whilst the second half gives instruction on coping with behavioural changes and reinforcing gender roles, with a marriage scene followed by a picture of a young woman with her baby, suggesting “the natural course of life”. When this film was screened in schools, girls received a copy of a booklet, “Very Personally Yours”, which pushed Kotex products.

results.title: Spread your wings: making it with TAFE
results.creator_credit: John O'Shea, Chris Stewart, Technical and Further Education and Documentary Films
results.brief_description: An impressionistic film which is intended to provide information about the opportunities offered by Technical and Further Education in vocational training, and in recreational courses to meet community requirements. It is not intended to give detailed information on the breadth of courses and curricula but is rather a stimulus film aimed at encouraging enrolment.
